document.masterDocTitle: The genus Micandra Staudinger (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae: Theclinae) in Colombia, with the description of a new species from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Micandra Staudinger (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae: Theclinae) in Colombia, with the description of a new species from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pseudolycaena platyptera C. Felder & R. Felder
[ 1865 ]: 246 , pl. 28 : figs. 6, 7 . D’Abrera 1995 : 1133 ; holotype 3 illustrated.
Pseudolycaena cadmus C. Felder & R. Felder
[ 1865 ]: 247 , pl. 31 : fig. 5 .

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Egides cadmus
(C. Felder & R. Felder, [ 1865 ]);
Johnson, Kruse & Kroenlein 1997
: 17
.

Macusia cadmus
(C. Felder & R. Felder, [ 1865 ]);

.

Micandra sylvia

, pl. 16 : fig. B; ( holotype examined).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Taxonomic history and remarks.
Micandra platyptera
was described from at least two males from Venezuela and Colombia by C. Felder & R. Felder. In the same work the authors described a unique female as
Pseudolycaena cadmus
, which subsequently was associated with
M. platyptera
by
Goodson ( 1946 )
. The last action was accepted by
Clench ( 1971 )
,
Robbins ( 1986 )
,
Bridges ( 1994 )
, and D’Abrera ( 1995 ). However, Johnson et al. ( 1997 ) placed the name
Pseudolycaena cadmus
in a new combination as
Egides cadmus
and, inexplicably a few pages later, established another new combination as
Macusia cadmus
.

Le Crom and Johnson ( 1997 )
described
Micandra sylvia
from a single Colombian male collected in Caquetá. This species was listed as a synonym of
M. platypera
by
Robbins ( 2004 )
. I studied the holotype and found that the extremely bright blue dorsum, enlarged forewing brand, and vaguely marked hindwing venter, features given by
Le Crom and Johnson ( 1997 )
as diagnostic, fall within the variation of
M. platyptera
males. Several
Micandra
species described by Johnson et al. ( 1997 ) were transferred to or synonymized with species in
Timaeta
by
Robbins & Busby ( 2008 )
.

Diagnosis.
Micandra platyptera
may be confused with
M. extrema
; however,
M. platyptera
is easily distinguished from all other
Micandra
species by the following: males lack tails on the hindwings, the wings are very truncate, and the ventral side of the hindwing is dark brown with an extremely jagged pattern.

Distribution. In Colombia
Micandra platyptera
is known from the three Cordilleras at elevations between 1000 m and 1900 m .
